title: 108_s1300
content: The Act is titled the "Prescription Drug Consumer Information Act of 2003" and includes transparency requirements for pharmacy benefit managers under the Public Health Service Act. The "Prescription Drug Consumer Information Act of 2003" imposes requirements on pharmacy benefit managers (PBMs) in group health plans and health insurance coverage. PBMs must not be owned by pharmaceutical companies, pass cost savings to the plan or issuer, and disclose the percentage of manufacturer rebates returned to the plan or issuer annually. The Prescription Drug Consumer Information Act of 2003 imposes requirements on pharmacy benefit managers (PBMs) in group health plans and health insurance coverage. PBMs must provide financial and utilization information annually to the plan or issuer, designated as confidential if necessary. The Prescription Drug Consumer Information Act of 2003 requires pharmacy benefit managers (PBMs) in group health plans and health insurance coverage to disclose financial terms and arrangements with drug manufacturers. The amendment applies to group health plans and health insurance issuers for plan years starting after the Act's enactment date. The Public Health Service Act is amended to redesignate a subpart as subpart 2 and add new provisions at the end. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include transparency requirements for pharmacy benefit managers in the individual market, similar to group health plans. The effective date for this amendment is upon the enactment of the Act. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include transparency requirements for pharmacy benefit managers in the individual market, similar to group health plans. This amendment applies to plan years beginning on or after the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will require pharmacies to disclose the retail cost of prescription drugs upon consumer request.
